arguments.text: Zombies are no longer human when they turn.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Zombies do not change much physically, are basically undead humans, and are the same but insane.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: A banana does not undergo much change when it rots.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Zombies completely become monsters that crave human flesh.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Zombies are a result of an infection.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: No virus has ever been known to turn infected animal species into something else.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: Nothing that can take multiple bullets in the chest and still stand should be considered human.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: A zombie is a human, just a dead one.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: Zombies do not have any working internal organs to lose.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: Arguing about zombies is tricky because they are depicted differently in various stories.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: Batman is still human because he relies on gadgets and suits, and his iron will, drive, and intelligence carry him.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: The Flash, Aquaman, or Starlord are not considered human.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Starlord is not human because his father is an alien god.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Spiderman is a human.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Spiderman's transformation was not as drastic as others.
arguments.speaker: S1

arguments.text: Spiderman's transformation is similar in scale to The Flash's transformation.
arguments.speaker: S2

arguments.text: Even if an entity becomes 'something else' evolutionarily speaking, it does not stop being what it was.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: The Flash is a metahuman, but he is still a human.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Atlanteans might be a type of alien, but they are likely just metahumans.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Starlord is just a human, and there doesn't seem to be anything special about him.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Starlord's father being an alien does not negate Starlord's humanity if the alien is genetically compatible with humans.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Only a creationist would argue against the law of cladistics.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: It goes against all known rules of biology to 'stop being what you are in order to become something else'.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Instead of stopping being what you are, you remain what you are and gain additional adaptations.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Zombies are humans; they are just infected.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: The definition of human is not contingent on how many bullets one can withstand.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Birds are, in fact, dinosaurs, because they do not stop being what their ancestors were.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Tadpoles are not fish; they are still frogs in an early phase of their life cycle.
arguments.speaker: S4

arguments.text: Frog eggs are premature frogs, tadpoles are juvenile frogs, adult frogs are adult frogs, and dead frogs are dead frogs; they are all the same species.
arguments.speaker: S4

arguments.text: A dead human is a dead human.
arguments.speaker: S4

arguments.text: A zombie has a relationship with the dead human body, inhabiting part of it like a hermit crab inhabits a part of a dead mollusk.
arguments.speaker: S4

arguments.text: The hermit crab analogy applies to biological zombies, but not supernatural zombies.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Supernatural zombies do not require explanation.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Supernatural zombies are a weaker premise because they hold up less to investigation.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Bio zombies are still wearing the trappings of their meatbag hosts.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Bio zombies could be considered a hybrid organism due to evolutionary symbiosis.
arguments.speaker: S3

arguments.text: Zombies still have human qualities because they are still human.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: Cannibalism exists.
arguments.speaker: S6

arguments.text: A rotten banana is still a banana, just rotten.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: A dead human is still biologically a human.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: A human corpse is not a 'person' per se.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Self-defense is a valid concept.
arguments.speaker: S10

arguments.text: Individuals lose their rights the moment they desire human flesh.
arguments.speaker: S10

arguments.text: Some types of zombies retain thoughts and the ability to speak.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: Zombies infected by a virus or fungus progressively lose their humanity.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: Freakers in Days Gone are humans who are more animalistic and stronger than average people.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: In The Last of Us, a fungus gradually takes control, first affecting mobility, then leading to a complete loss of humanity.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: Night of the Living Dead type zombies are completely dead, devoid of humanity and intelligence.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: Individuals under a voodoo curse are 100% human, merely obedient slaves until the curse is lifted.
arguments.speaker: S11

arguments.text: Zombies are half-human because they still resemble humans, but their bodies are not under their control.
arguments.speaker: S14

arguments.text: Zombies are physically human.
arguments.speaker: S15

arguments.text: Zombies are not mentally human.
arguments.speaker: S15

arguments.text: Both humans and zombies are edible.
arguments.speaker: S15

arguments.text: Zombies are still human, as their bodies are human bodies that have rotted, been infected, or mutated.
arguments.speaker: S16

arguments.text: Humanity, encompassing emotional and mental aspects, can be lost.
arguments.speaker: S16

arguments.text: Many types of zombies still have the human alive, but under external control.
arguments.speaker: S16

arguments.text: A zombie is a human.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: The emotional distress experienced by individuals who see a loved one as a zombie indicates that zombies are still recognized as the person they once were.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: A zombie virus is a disease, and its carrier is still human, similar to how a person with cancer is still a person.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: Zombies are not fully human.
arguments.speaker: S17

arguments.text: The transformation into a zombie removes essential human qualities such as rational thought, self-awareness, and moral decision-making.
arguments.speaker: S17

arguments.text: Severe mental and biological changes in zombies signify a fundamental shift from being human to something new.
arguments.speaker: S17

arguments.text: Zombies are undead, representing a human in a state of decomposition and unconsciousness.
arguments.speaker: S18

arguments.text: According to some lore, zombies are not technically human but also not typical zombies; they are mutated or evolved humans.
arguments.speaker: S19

arguments.text: The Autophage results in a gene change after several generations of humans, leading to a new species.
arguments.speaker: S19

arguments.text: Zombies do not fit the Cambridge dictionary definition of 'human' because they lack qualities, faults, and feelings typical of people and are unable to think.
arguments.speaker: S20

arguments.text: Typical zombies lack feelings and many human qualities, resembling infected animals from a human perspective.
arguments.speaker: S20

arguments.text: The dictionary defines zombies as corpses brought back, usually through witchcraft.
arguments.speaker: S22

arguments.text: The definition of a zombie does not require them to be human.
arguments.speaker: S22

arguments.text: Zombies are the undead form of their living creature counterpart.
arguments.speaker: S23

arguments.text: Undead humans are zombies.
arguments.speaker: S23

arguments.text: A zombie is still human, despite being heavily altered.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: Someone with the flu is still human.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: A rotting corpse is still human.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: Zombies are reanimated humans.
arguments.speaker: S5

arguments.text: Zombies are still human because their species does not change, only their behavior.
arguments.speaker: S24

arguments.text: The morality of killing zombies is not an issue, as they kill and infect others.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: If being a zombie is beneficial, then everyone should be converted to zombism.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: The consciousness, memories, and everything that makes a person human dies when they become undead.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: An undead body is technically still 'human' (a human corpse) until it decomposes.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: The mind of an undead zombie is either controlled by a necromancer or is non-existent, functioning as a flesh-eating organism without human thought and emotion.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Undead beings are no longer human, but merely human bodies or corpses.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: The body of an infected zombie is human, but the mind, consciousness, soul, or essence of the person is absent.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Infected zombies are shells of humans inhabited by a viral infection that uses the body as a host.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: There are no human conditions that exhibit zombie-like tendencies such as lack of emotion, reasoning, or thought.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Infected zombies, lacking emotion and reasoning, should not be called human.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Shaun of the Dead's dead Nick Frost, who still plays videogames, is an exception and remains human despite being a cannibalistic sociopath.
arguments.speaker: S8

arguments.text: Zombies are the undead counterpart of humans.
arguments.speaker: S13

arguments.text: Once individuals turn into zombies, they are no longer human.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Zombies are reanimated dead.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Zombies lack a soul, which is essential to being human.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Zombies cannot use their brains effectively.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: In most media, characters must die before turning into zombies.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Zombies are walking balls of rotting flesh driven by endless hunger.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Anything that lives after death is no longer human.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: Zombies are missing many qualities that define a human, such as emotion.
arguments.speaker: S26

arguments.text: The world is a zombie, and humans are living in it.
arguments.speaker: S27

arguments.text: A brain is necessary to function in this world.
arguments.speaker: S27

arguments.text: Donating thoughts and time to the world is equivalent to donating the brain's precious time.
arguments.speaker: S27
